Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Sat urdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dar danelles, Gallipoli, and Constantinople.
SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railw ays express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA LINE.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo, and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, and Aden.
For further information refer to the Co's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to the Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt) Ltd., Hamburg-Amerika Reise-Bureau or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head:
The Egyptian Gazette
THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager--R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
SOUTH AFRICAN LOYALTY
div.p: Loyalty to the Crown is happily an axiom in all parts of the Empire. The subjects of the King, in whatever quarter of the world they may be, and however diverse their sentiment in other respects, are at least united in the respect they pay to the supreme head of all. They consider it unnecessary to mark their loyalty by effusive gifts : they would hold it absurd to suspect that loyalty was lacking or lukewarm in the absence of such gifts. And the older States of the Empire have extended the same feeling of confidence to the newest addition to them all : General Botha and his Cabinet have taken the oath of fealty as His Majesty's Ministers; we look on our Boer fellow-subjects in the same way as upon the French-Canadians, as foreigners by race, but as British as we ourselves in honourable allegiance. That being so —and General Botha during his late visit to England was careful to emphasize his loyalty on several occasions— it may perhaps be regarded as a work of supererogation on the part of the Transvaal Government says the "Globe" to propose to present the great Cullinan diamond to the King. That its eventual destination should be the British Crown, side by side with the Koh-i-Noor and the other precious gems of the Imperial diadem, few would be found to question. But that the present moment should have been chosen for the gift seems inadvisable. Such a gift, to be acceptable, should be the unanimous act of the whole Transvaal Legislature; as it is, the Pro gressive party will be forced to oppose a suggestion that looks extravagant at a time when the Colony is in a state of not too great prosperity and industrial stability. If the Progressives refuse to vote for the acquisition and presentation of the Cullinan diamond, their action may be misunderstood in some quarters. It will certainly be assailed in others. More especially will it be the subject of vituperation in those Radical circles in Great Britain which find pleasure in distorting every motive of their fellow countrymen in South Africa, and in uttering hysterical glorifications of every Boer leader. Yet we have no doubt that their action is dictated by motives of sincerity, and not by any factious desire, the truest loyalty to the King lies in forwarding the prosperity of his dominions, and not in spending hundreds of thousands that cannot be afforded. The Crown's most resplendent Oriental jewel is not the Koh-i-Noor, but the work of the British Raj in India: a far finer gift from South Africa than the Cullinan diamond would be the news that the sub-continent stood at last on as firm a foundation as the other self-governing States of the Empire, and that it was developing as rapidly and as peacefully as they. In considering the question we must remember that the finances of the Transvaal are in such a condition that the British Government have had to guarantee it a loan of five millions sterling, and that therefore the precious gift will, in sense, be purchased with our own money ; and that this extravagance will lead to enforced administrative economies which will necessitate the retirement of a large number of Englishmen from the public service of the colony. The period of tension through which South Africa as a whole is passing has been strikingly proved daring the last fortnight. The Budget of Cape Colony, introduced at Cape Town on Monday last, showed a deficit of £640,455. The revenue has fallen from £11,250,000 to £7,000,000 in four years. And next year, in spite of additions to the Income-Tax and other revisions and economies, a deficit of nearly £300,000 is anticipated. Natal is still feeling the cost of the native disturbances early last year. The Orange River Colony, as a purely agricultural State, has indeed no pressing problems, either financial or economic, to face ; but the railway difficulty affects it as well as the other provinces. And the shifts to which the Transvaal is reduced by its enforced gratitude to the British Government and the consequent necessity for interference with the supply of coolie labour, is sufficiently indicated by its abortive Liquor and Native Administration Bills. In these diffioult circumstances, to refrain from extravagances of any kind is the first duty of all the Governments concerned. After a few years of economical administration and political quiet, federation would be not merely a local aspiration or a states man's dream: it would be an accomplished fact. When that time comes, a symbolic gift to the Crown would be a graceful act : at present, it is unfortanately open to misconstruction.

div.head: Sudden Attack.
div.p: While Saleh Bey Soubhy, ex-Inspector Sanitary Department Cairo, was walking at San Stephano on Saturday last he was followed by Habib Bey Moularak's cook, who struck him with a stick on the shoulders and injured him. The cause is attributed to family matters.

div.head: Escape from Drowning.
div.p: Yesterday morning while Hussain Akad, son of Hassan Akad, was at San Stephano taking a bath he was carried off by the waves and was on the point of being drowned but was rescued by his friend Ibrahim Bey Fadel who endangered his life and brought him back safely.

div.head: Striking a Journalist.
div.p: While the Editor of- the Greek paper "Khromos" was driving in his carriage near Caffé de Chicha, Cairo, on Friday,a man struck him with a stick on the head and injured him. It is said that the attack was dne to the Editor publishing something against him in his paper.

div.head: Cotton Market.
div.p: Messrs. Collinge Brothers, Liverpool, report under date of the 17th inst that the market during the past week has had a downward tendency, showing a net loss of 154 to 18 points compared with last week's closing prices. The chief cause of the decline has been the unsettled state of affairs in the Stock Exchanges together with somewhat better crop reports, principally from Texas, where the drought had caused so much anxiety lately. The principal item of interest has been Messrs. Giles' semi-monthly report, issued yesterday, showing an average condition of the crop of 75.8 against 76.8 a fortnight and 76.2 a month ago.
SILVESTER v. MONTANO.

The case of Messrs Sylvester & Co. v. Mr. A. A. Montano for dishonoured bills to the amount of nearly. £5,000 was heard at the British Consulate this morning by Mr. Grieg, acting Consul, with Mr. Abdy and Mr. Walter F, Sarjeant as assessors. Mr. Montano applied for an adjournment of the case, which, however, the Court refused, the application being on the ground of insufficient time to obtain legal representation. Judgment was eventually given in favor of the plaintiffs with costs, The case of the plaintiffs was conducted by Mr. Halford. Mr. Montano conducted his own defence.

div.head: ROWING CLUBS REGATTA
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir,—I wonder how many sports men witnessed the racing between the four Rowing Clubs of Alexandria yesterday in the harbour without being amused at the farce the same represented. Of the four races two were "row-overs"; and in the other two fouls occurred and nobody knew who was the winner. There was apparent ly no umpire but a sort of Committee launch which also acted as starter. At the end of each race this launch was besieged by some of the competitors and their compatriots, and it appeared to an onlooker that the one who shouted the loudest won the race. This was particularly the case after the sculling race when one gentleman went along side the launch in a boat specially to fight the cause of his man. Why was there no independent umpire who should have been in a launch of this own and whose decision should be absolutely final? Apparently these things are not understood here like they are in Europe.
Yours truly,
Britisher.
Alexandria, August 26.

div.head: THE LATE MADAME AGHION.
div.p: The body of the late Madame Aghion, wife of Monsieur Joseph I. Aghion, who died st La Bourboule on the 14th inst., will arrive at Alexandria to-morrow morning ly the Messageries Maritimes mail boat, and will be conveyed direct to the honse of the deceased, No. 1, Rue Sidi el Kiachi, Kom el Dik, from where the funeral cor tege will start at 4.30 p.m. Friends are re quested to accept this intimation as an in vitation to attend.

div.head: APPEAL TO FOREIGN SECRETARY.
div.p: We have received, with the rest of the press, a copy of the programme of the self dubbed "Egyptian National Party" issued by the "Egyptian Committee," whatever that may mean—under cover of a letter from Hafiz Awad, of the "Al Minbar." This gentle man, as will be remembered, was Mr. Ro bertson's guide, philosopher and friend, dur ing the cursory visit which he paid to this country during last winter, and it may be presumed that in return for services render ed Mr. Robertson has lent a helping hand in compiling his new Egyptian Constitution. It is accepted on all hands that it requir es many years of careful and patient study before one can be in a position to put one self forward as an authority on such mo mentous questions, and one has only to read the proposals to at once realize that its authors have neither the requisite know ledge to deal with such complex problems, nor can one believe they have Egypt's real welfare at heart. The following are the com munications addressed to Sir Edward Grey:—

To the
Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.
Sir,
I have the honour to submit to you the en closed outline of the views and wishes of the Egyptian nation as regards the changes in the Administration of Egypt which we have reason to believe will be satisfactory to our people, having been already sanctioned by the General Assembly at its recent meeting, and which appear to us to be of a nature which His Majesty's Government may properly agree to.
The proposals for establishing the Constitu tion which I have the honour to submit, are based on the schemes put forward by the Earl of Dufferin in 1883. These proposals are capable of expansion or modification as may be deemed expedient when the details are ar ranged; but we venture to think that they are the minimum of the reforms necessary for the reasonable satisfaction of the Egyptian people, in accordance with the pledges repeatedly given to them by the Representatives of His Majesty's Government.
I may add that copies of this letter and the enclosure will be torwarded to Members of Parliament and the Press.
I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your most Obedient Servant,
A. Hapiz Awad.
Editor-Proprietor of "Al-Minbar,"
Cairo.

div.head: PROGRAMME OF THE EGYPTIAN NATIONAL PARTY.
div.p: PRINCIPLE POINTS,
1. Free and compulsory education in Kut tabs and Primary Schools.
2. Arabic to be the medium of instruction in all schools.
3. The creation of a constitution under which Legislative Council, so far as concerns Egyptian interests.
4. Government officials of European nationali ty to be gradually replaced by Egyptians.
5. Criminal jurisdiction of Consular Courts to be transferred to Mixed Courts.
SUBSIDARY POINTS.
1. Release of Denshawai Prisoners and amendment of Decree of 1895, concerning the Special Court.
2. A Municipal Government for Cairo.
3. Village Omdehs to be elected by the whole mass of the villagers (owners and labourers alike).

div.head: PROPOSALS.
div.p: For Establishing an Egyptian Constitution, to include the Legislative Couneil and the General Assembly.

1. Electoral Law, 1883. — The only amend ment proposed is to substitute Direct for Indirect representation. In other words to abolish the "electeur délégué," and let the people vote directly for the Members who are to represent them in both Chambers.

2. Organic Law, 1883. — Retain two Cham- bers as at present. Let the Legislative Conncil be the Lower or First Chamber and the General Assembly the Second Chamber. Retain the same number of Members in the First Chamber, but sub stitute seven Under Secretaries of State— one for each Ministry—for seven of the nominated members. Second Chamber to be costituted as at present, save that the Members of the First Chamber are to be excluded therefrom, except when deli berating upon the Budget proposals. An nual Sessions of sufficient length to permit of proper discussion.

3. Qualification of Members of both Cham bers to be identical, viz., L.E. 20 paid in taxation on property per annum. This would necessitate the lowering of the property qualification for the First Chamber.
4. Sittings of both Chambers to be free to the Public and Press.
5. Rules or Procedure to be passed by a Joint Committee of both Chambers.
6. All Government measures to be intro duced into the First Chamber Private Members of both Chambers may ini tiate Legislation in the Chamber to which they belong.
7. No law from and after the promulgation of this decree to be valid unless it has been voted by both Cham bers and received the assent of His Highness the Khedive.
8. The veto of His Highness the Khedive may be overridden by a vote of two-thirds majority of both Chambers.
9. Accounts for preceding year and Budget to be presented to both Chambers on 1st March and to be dealt with by 31st March.
10. President and two Vice-Presidents for each Chamber to be elected by the Cham bers themselves.
11. Powers of Chambers. Full jurisdiction in all matters which are purely Egyptian.

12. Foreign residents—Foreigners not to be entitled to vote for Members of the Legislative Council and General Assem bly, but any limitations necessary to secure Foreign Powers and Foreigners from legislative interference to be ac cepted.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
AUGUST SKYE MEETING
div.p: From a racing point of view there was no cause for grumbling at Saturday's August Skye Meeting, but it is a pity these enjoyable "off season" gatherings are not more numerously attended. It gives the organisers no en couragement to increase the number of meet ings, which the majority of race-goers would no doubt appreciate. Amongst those present on Saturday no lack of enthusiasm was shown, and in spite of a couple of runaway wins by Kara Aslan, and the consistent Radium, the rest of the programme produced some interest ing and keen sport. An excellent selection of music was performed by the Band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers under the conductorship of Bandmaster A. Fawcett and it was with a feeling of regret, as one heard the strains of the National Anthem, to think that another month would elapse ere such an enjoyable atternoon would be repeated.
The following are the results:

STATISTICS OF SCHOOLS
CLASSIFICATION OF INSTITUTIONS
div.p: According to the statistical return of pupils attending public and private schools in Egypt issued by the statistical department of the Ministry of Finance, there were in 1906 throughout Egypt 505 schools with 92,107 pupils, 71,666 of which were males and 20,441 females. Of these 505 schools 200 were Egyptian institutions, 120 American, 85 French, 35 Italian, 29 Greek, 20 English, 9 Austrian, 4 German, 2 Dutch, and 1 Russian.

div.head: Location of Schools.
div.p: In Cairo there were 136 schools, in Alex andria 100, Port Said 20, Suez 20, Ismailia 5, and in the, fourteen moudiriehs of Egypt there were in all 235, Assient leading with 56 and being followed by Garbieh with 37, Minieh 23, Girgeh 20, Dakahlieh 15, Sharkieh 14, Menoufieh 14, Keneh 12, Fayoum 12, Galioubieh 9, Behera 9, Beni-Souef 7, Gizeh 4, and Assouan 3.

div.head: Teachery and Pupils.
div.p: Attached to the 200 Egyptian schools of Egypt there were 2,355teachers for 51,431 pupils of which 49,877 were Egyptians, and of the 305 foreign schools there were 1,986 teachers for 40,676 pupils, of which 20,578 were Egyptians. It will thus be seen that although there were 105 more foreign than Egyptian schools, the number of teachers attached to the latter exceeded the former by 369, and it is also notable that more than half the pupils of the foreign institations were Egyptians.

div.head: Egyptians and Foreigners.
div.p: Of the 92,107 pupils of the year under review 70,455 were Egyptians and 21,652 foreigners, as follows:—English 1,671; Austrian 864; French 1,492; German 506; Greek 7,700; Italian 5,901; and others 3,518. The great preponderance among foreigners of Greeks and Italians is here very noticeable. The number of foreigners receiving instruction in Egyptian institutions was 1,554, 21 of whom were English, 48 French, 74 Greek, 59 Italian, 15 Austrian, and 3 German.

div.head: Religion.
div.p: It is also interesting to note that of the total of 92,107 pupils 44,072 (less than half) were: Musulmans, 21,675 Copts, 9,013 Orthodox, 10,035 Catholics, 1,045 Protestants, and 5,981 Jews. Of the 20,441 female pupils, only 3,681 were Musalmans 2,192 of which attended Egyptian institutions

div.head: Age.
div.p: Of the total of 70,455 Egyptian pupils 914 were under five years, 2,695 five to six years, 4,458 six to seven, 5,985 seven to eight, 9,974 eight to ten, 10,956 ten to twelve, 10,877 twelve to fifteen, 5,353 fifteen to eighteen, 1,803 eighteen to twenty, and 1,320 above twenty years. Of the 21,652 foreigners 612 were under five years, 1,414 five to six, 2,119 six to seven, 2,342 seven to eight, 3,946 eight to ten, 4,119 ten to twelve, 3,951 twelve to fifteen, 1,339 fifteen to eighteen, 236 eighteen to twenty, and 63 about twenty years. The fall in the number of pupils between 15 to 18 years of age is somewhat remarkable, but can doubtless be accounted for by the number who are sent to Europe to complete their education.

div.head: Dates of Foundation.
div.p: The first Egyptian educational institution now existent, to be founded was, of course, Al Azhar University, the date of which is given as 972, and the next founded school which still exists was the Cairo Medical School, which dates back to 1824, after which came the Kalusdian School of the Orthodox Armenian Patriarchate in 1828. Since 1880 forty-one Egyptian educational in stitutions have been founded in Cairo 14 of which are private Musulman schools, and 11 of which depend upon the Egyptian Govern ment. Of the nine English institutions in Cairo five depend upon the Church Missionary Society, the first of which was founded in 1884. The American Mission founded a boys' school in Cairo in 1854 and a girls' school in 1856, Of the seven English educational institutions in Alexandria four depend upon the Church of Scottand Mission, and were all founded in 1860, one upon the Egypt General Mission, one upon the Maltese Benevolent Society and one, Victoria College, is private.

div.head: Victoria College.
div.p: The Victoria College, which was founded in 1902, had during the year under review twelve teachers with a total number of 210 pupils, of whom 17 were preparatory, 166 primary, and 27 secondary. Of these 210 pupils 72 were Egyptians, 15 English, 7 Austrian, 5 French, 1 German, 25 Greek, and 58 Italian. Seventy- six pupils of the college were Jews, 55 Musul mans, 12 Copts, 33 Orthodox, 23 Catholics, and 10 Protestants.

div.head: Al Azhar University.
div.p: At Al Azhar University there was a staff of 224 teachers and the total number of pupils was 9,069, of which 8,458 were Egyptians, 279 Syrians, 123 Turks, 147 Moroccans, 13 Kurds, and 15 Abyssinians

div.head: Kuttabs.
div.p: The total number of kuttabs in Egypt at the end of 1906 was 4,554 with a staff of 6,850 teachers giving instruction to 152,748 boys and 12,839 girls. Of these kuttabs 122 were Governmental, and 4,432 were under inspection, 2,768 of which were subsidised. It is interesting to note that in 1890 the number of kuttabs was 50, by 1900 the number had risen to 569 and during the subsequent five years the number increased by 3,601, these being 4,698 kuttabs in 1905.

div.head: Reformatory and Police Schools.
div.p: In the Cairo police school, which was founded in 1900, there were 16 teachers during last year and 370 pupils, 300 of whom were non-paying and all of whom were boarded. 350 of the pupils were Musulmans and 270 of them were between the ages of 15 and 20 years. In the reformatory school at Ghizeh there were 8 teachers and 382 pupils, 373 of whom were Musulmans, 8 Copts, and 1 Jew. Three of the pupils were children between six and seven years of age, 84 between eight and ten, 171 between ten and twelve, 115 between twelve and fifteen, and 9 between fifteen and eighteen. In both of these institutions all the pupils are of Egyptian nationality.

div.head:
A EUROPEAN "RAG."
A DISGRACEFUL EXHIBITION
div.p: Consequent to the regatta of yesterday held by the four rowing clubs of Alexandria, some forty or fifty members thereof decided to pass the evening by indulging in a "rag", Commencing at the Germania Bar, where they comported themselves with perfect repectability, they consumed a quantity of beer which must have been gratifying to the heart of the proprietor.

About half past ten, the party proceeded to the Olympia café chantant, where, we are informed by the proprieter, who showed us, the broken property, 6 chairs, 1 table in wood and 2 in iron, and 6 glasses were broken while to make matters worse the debanchers forced their way into the music hall without even offering to pay entrance.

After leaving the Olympia, which they had taken care to make as objectionable as possible by throwing small blocks of ice, which they carried, on the ground, and from which they had compelled several persons to leave, owing to their rowdiness, the party proceeded to the Tour Eiffel, and enjoyed themselves by extinguishing on route the street lamps and stopping the arabeahs which they met, in order to extinguish theirs'. Opposite the Tour Eiffel a lamp was extinguished by one of the party who, being arrested by a shawish, was promptly rescued by his comrades. At the Tour Eiffel an entrance fee of one piastre tariff per head was offered, and we are not surprised that this was promptly refused. In no way deterred, however, by the refusal, the party charged through the obstructing proprietor and his staff and swarmed into the boxes, from which they took with them six hat racks.

It is notable, and altogether foreign to the custom of respectable Europeans, whatever their state of inebriety may be, that though doing considerable harm to both places of entertainment by refusing to pay entrance, stealing the hat racks, and breaking chairs etc., not a single half piastre, according to the information of the proprietors, was expended by the party.

From the Tour Eiffel the party proceeded to Walker and Meimarachi's bar, which they passed through almost without halting, and from there a detachment went to the Belle Vue café where they created a great disturbance by shouting and singing. Chairs were broken, the globes of the electric light installation were removed, and the debauchers generally disgusted the public by their uproarious behaviour.

Reports of further disgraceful conduct have reached us, but these we refrain from reproducing these as we having been unable to obtain confirmation. The report that we have given above has been confirmed by personal visits to the various scenes of the debauchery, and interviews with the proprietors concerned.

The proprietor of the Olympia having warned the police authorities of the scenes which were being enacted, a captain of the police was sent to watch the party and see that no serious harm was done, and from the moment that he arrived he followed their every movement

The public, however, is asking why was this "rag" allowed to reach such a stage, and why did the police give such a remarkable exhibition of their feebleness inefficiency by allowing such a disturbance to continue unchecked. Well may our French contemporaries ironically head their articles on the police service "Nos bons chaoniches".

The rowing clubs will be interested to learn that the proprietors of the Tour Eiffel and the Olympia music halls have decided to taken action against their committees in the Mixed Tribunals. The proprietor of the former informs us that his claim against the clubs will amount to at least £10,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd kui a 11h. 1/2 a.m.).

Malgré une animation apparente, le marché de ce matin a été dans son ensemble terne et sans allure bien définie. A part quelques valeurs d'ordre secondaire,en particulier la Delta Land et les Estates, qui ont donné lien 4 un certain nombre d'échanges, les autres sont restées sans transactions appréciables. Il n'y a dailleors aucun motif Ace marasme autre que le calme habituel de la saison d'été. Avec un chiffre si réduit d'affaires et en l'absence d'une tendance précise on comprend que les fluctuations n'aient eu aucune importance.
Une demande qui s'est produite en Agricole e National Bank a relevé leurs cours respectifs de 8 et 20 a 81/82 et 20 3/16.

En hausse également, pour une raison ana- logue, la Privilégi¢e Biére d'Alexandrie de 145 & 148, PObligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 200 & 301, les Splendid Hotels de 4a 4 3/16 et l'Union Fonciére de 4 1/2 a 4 9/16.
Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie fiéchissent, au contraire, de 143 4 142 1/2, les Lote*Turcs de 158 4 157 et le Banco di Roma de 105 4-104.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Markets recu- lent de 27/6 & 27, la Salt and Soda de 18/64 18/8, la Cassa di Sconto de 38 4 37, POrdinary Khedivial Mail de-22/6 4 22, les Estates de 23/82 4 11/16, le Comptoir Fin. et Commer- cial de 2 11/16 4 2 1/2 Yancienne, de 2 5/842 7/16 la nouvelle et de 23/4 4 2 1/2 la part de fondateor, la Building Lands de 2 1/4 4 2 8/16 vendeurs, la fondateur United de'2 1/44 2°1/8, les Ritz de 11/16 4 5/8 et !Héouan de 9/32 4 1/4. Seules les Delta Land bénéficient de 1/32 41 29/82 acheteurs.

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan- gements 4 signaler. On voit que, aprés le dé- laimsement des grosses valeurs ees jours der- niers, c'est maintenant le tour des petites, jus- qu'& ce qu'un nouvean revirement se produise a lear profit. Ces mouvements en sens inverse, | d'ailleurs insignifianta, n'ont qu'ane importance relative, tant que les affaires demeurent anasi limtitées, Il sont unesimple manifestation pas- sagere de Voffre et de la demande, sans autre conséquence pour les détentears. Il en sera an- trement 4 Vapproche de Vhiver, lorsque |'acti- vité auta repris.

Pour le moment c'est surtout un travail d'é- limination qui s'effectae, an profit des titres solides et dont la dépréciation a ¢té exagérée. Le capitaliste fait son choix et jette gradnelle- ment Vivraie pour ne conserver que le bon grain. Les badands /qui ne s'en dontent pas seront tout étonnés' 4 la reprise des affaires de voir que ta _hatese ne se produit pas sur toute la ligne et que leurstitres se trouvent précisément dans la catégorie retardataire.

div.head: GOMMES ARABIQUES
div.p: La saison est terminée. Les derniers lots qu'il y avaita Duem étaient plus ou moins endommagés par les pluies et se sont vendus 4 P.T. 83 le cantar de 140 rotolis (100 rotolis de gomme équivalent 4 kilos 45). A Omdur- man, on @ pratiqué le prix de P.T. 95 le canter de 110 rotolis,pour un ou deux lots senlement, les derniers de la saison. Contrairement aux années précédentes, en pareille saison, il n'y a pas de stock a Omdurman.
Cette année-ci, les prix ont eu une tendance presque continuelle 4 la hausse. Ceci est df aux deux causes suivantes:
1° La récolte des gommes au Sénégal ayant &éte trés mauvaise, les divers marchés d'Europe n'ont pu s'y approvisionner 4 bon compte et ont df accepter la hausse quien est résaltée au Soudan.

2°. Bien que l'année derniére il y ait eu des pluies torrentielles, ce qui prédispose toujours les arbres & produire beaucoup de gomme, les indigénes, natarellement indolents, pour ne pas dige fainéants, ayant.eu une bonne récolte de lear assurant de quoi vivre,ont négligé complétement de recueillir la gomme.
C'est ainsi que, bien que les arbres du.Kor- dofan aient donné cet année beaucoup de gommeé d'une qualité exceptionnellement bonne, personne n'a pa en profiter puisqu'elle n'a pas été recueillie.
En 1906, pour les 6 mois del'année, l'ex- portation des gommes d'Egypte se répartissait comme suit:
En 1907, cette exportation se réduit comme suit:
soit une difference en moins pour cette annee de kilos 1.830.145 valant L.E. 41.627.

Il est a remarquer qu'en 1907 des expeditions de gomme ont ete faites directement de Port-Soudan en Europe et en Australie; ces expeditions peuvent etre estimees frosso modo au dixieme du total de l'exportation.

Il est trop tot pour parler de la prochaine campagne, mais comme il a deja plu a torrents au Soudan, il est a presager qu'il y aura encore une abendas te recolte de mais et que les indigenes ne voudront pas davantage se donner la peine de recueillir la gomme, a moins que les prix eleves des scheteurs, ne soient un stimulant pour les moins paresseux.

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA SITUATION
SULTAN MARCHING ON CASABLANCA
GERMAN COLONY LEAVING FEZ.

div.p: The reconnoitring was carried to within seven kilometres of the town without meeting any resistance. (Havas)
The Consuls at Morocco have telegraphed that the Sultan Moulay Hafid is marching on Casablanca. (Havas)
The German colony will leave Fez on Monday. (Havas)
All available troops here have been sent to reinforce the Moorish army which was recently sharply defeated by the Kmass tribesmen. (Retuer)

The Spanish troops have left the town to find a suitable: camp. They will not return to the town but will continue to co-operate with the French. Further French reinforcements and supplies have arrived. (Reuter)

div.head:
KING AT MARIENBAD.
INTERVIEW WITH CLEMENCEAU.

div.p: The "Politische Correspondenz" in an authorised statement remarks that the three recent royal meetings and the conversation between King Edward and M. Clémenceau at Marienbad have effected a harmonious European agreement. The general wish for peace has never before found such imposing expression. (Reuter)

div.head:
DISLOYALTY IN DUBLIN,
UNION JACK TORN DOWN.

div.p: A crowd at Dalkey, in County Dublin, tore town the Union Jack hoisted on the Town Hall in honour of the Atlantic fleet and threw it into the harbour. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
LEGATIONS AND EMBASSIES.

div.p: Russia and Japan have decided to raise their respective legations to the status of Embassies. A Bill for this purpose will be introduced at the opening o the new Duma. (Reuter)

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND ITALY.
MACEDONIANS REFORM SCHEME.

div.p: A communiqué states that Baron Aehrenthal and Signor Tittoni met on Thursday at Semmering, near Vienna, and confirmed the programme decided upon at Desio. Italy has accepted the Macedonian reform scheme, thus showing complete identity of Austro-Italian views regarding Balkan affairs. (R.)
In their interviews, Mr. Tittoni and Baron Aerenthal confirmed their approval of the Desio agreement. (Havas)
Baron von Aehrenthal and Signer Tittoni have arrived here. The Emporer Franz Joseph had a most cordial interview with Signor Tittoni. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SOCIALIST CONGRESS.
PREVENTION OF WAR.

div.p: The Socialist Congress voted a motion, presented by M.M. Guesde and Bebel, to provide for measures preventing war, and means serving to emancipate the proletariat. The next Congress will be held at Copenhagen in 1910. (Havas)

div.head:
OYSTER BAY CONFERENCE.
FLEET FOR PACIFIC.

div.p: At the Oyster Bay Conference President Roosevelt and the naval officials decided upon the details of the visit of the 16 battleships which leave for the Pacific in December. (R.)

div.head:
AMERICA'S COMMERCIAL NEEDS.
PROVISIONS OF TREASURER.

div.p: The Treasurer will begin next week to the national banks, and will continue to do so far at least five weeks in order to meet the commercial needs and prevent the stringency disturbing the business world. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE LIBERAL GOVERNMENT.
QUESTION OF THE LORDS.

div.p: Mr. Asquith, speaking at Corsham, Mr. Haldane at Kippenhouse, and Mr. Winston Churchill at Cheadle again brought the question to the forefront, emphasizing that the Lords' claim to coequal legislative rights with the Commons was the most serious political question. Mr. Winston Churchill said that the bills rejected by the Lords would be repassed very speedly till the time was suitable to ask the country for its verdict by democracy instead of by class. (Reuter)

div.head:
BURY ST. EDMONDS
HEAVY UNIONIST MAJORITY.

div.p: Bury St. Edmonds bye election. Mr. Walter Guiness, Unionist candidate, has been elected with 1631 votesin place of Captain Hervey, now the Marquis of Bristol. Mr. Yates, the Liberal candidate, had 741 votes. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRENCH TRAIN COLLISION,
TWELVE PERSONS KILLED.

div.p: The Bordeaux to Paris express collided with a goods train at Contras: 12 persons have been killed and 30 injured. (Reuter)
The prorogation of Parliament has been fixed for 28th instant. (Reuter)

The Turco-Persian frontier dispute threatens to become grave. Turkey repudiates the Persian claims, declaring that the whole of the occupied territory is properly Turkish. The Kurds are maltreating Persian inhabi tants. (Reuter)
HOUSE OF LORDS.-The House sat to-day: the English Land Bill passed the third reading. (Reuter)
M. Cambon has arrived here on a visit to Prince von Buelow. (Reuter)
The "Temeraire," the third ship of the "Dreadnought" class of tonnage of 18650, has been launched at Devonport. (Reuter)
Middlesex beat Sussex by 11 runs. Essex beat Derbyshire by 222 runs. The following matehes were drawn: Kent v. Yorkshire and Worcestershire v. Surrey (Reuter)

div.head:
"FELLAH" IN FINANCE
AN AMERICAN VIEW.
div.p: The "Egyptian situation" says "The New York Tribune" is a term which has appeared for the first time in cable dispatches within the last few weeks. No one knows exactly who or what a Pharaoh was, except that one of them had something to do with various plagues brought about by his refusal to follow the advice of the Jewish Moses. A "fellah" is not revised spelling for the "fellow" who lives by agricultural pursuits on land fertilized by the Nile. "Pharaoh" may be taken, however, as the equivalent of the master of the situation, while the "fellah" is the cotton planter, who is becoming increasingly—and unpleasantly—an important power in the financial world. If not as great as the American King Cotton, he holds the next highest rank.

When Wall Street shivers because Holland takes $500,000 in double eagles and Berlin obtains $1,000,000 in gold bars, while £500,000 is passing through Vienna on its way to Cairo, paid for by consols at a record low price, and the Continental banks take five-sixths of the weekly output of the Rand mines, and all this happéns in a week, it is evident that Egyptian cotton and its planter and owner are financial factors of great magnitude. The foremost security of the world, the British consol, has been offered for sale, at constantly lowering prices, in millions, from a source variously described as the Caisse (Egyptian Sub-Treasury), the Egyptian government, and the Egyptian banks, which were never hitherto suspected of having a surplus to invest at 8 per cent. There is, therefore, a feeling that, as in the case of the Baring failure, the sales of these consols show that one (or more) of the old conservative banking houses in London is carrying Egyptians at the expense of its English investments,

The "fellah" is rapidly becoming a kind of Mahdi or Raisuli. He is raiding the banks all around the world and carrying their reserves to his hoards. The important question now is. What will he do with his next crop? This is interesting St. Petersburg and Yokohama, as well as Boston and Manchester.

It is an indisputable fact that for more than a thousand years, from A.D 700 to A.D. 1876 more gold and silver went into Egypt than ever came out. The cotton crops of 1860-76 were sold for £530,000,000, and there was no gold worth mentioning retained during that period in the United States. But in 1876 Mr. Goschen, M. de Blignieres, Major Baring, R.A. and Rivers Wilson visited Egypt in the interests of the European capitalists. Thenceforth the hoards of both "Pharaoh" and "'fellah" began to be depleted. Gold by the ton and silver in quantity as well as value, at 16 to 1, flowed out to all points of the compass north of the equator.

In 1892 there were no more hoards and no more princes. The "fellahah" or peasant girl, wore a brass hangle instead of a silver one. The cotton crop after 1876 was taken to pay interest on debts fabricated to meet the demand, and so far as exchange was concerned it cost Europe nothing. But about ten years ago the tide showed signs of changing, and Pactolus is now running a veritable Colorado River into the Egyptian Salton Sea.

The gold arrives at Alexandria and disappears. According to the chairman of the Egyptian Estates Limited, £125,000,000, vanished last year. The Fellah is apparently willing to repeat the operation in the ensuing twelve months. He does not care for paper money, and has no more stomach for "interest bearing securities" than for champagne or bottled beer. So there is "nothing doing" on the Cotton Exchange of Alexandria, and as manufacturers of the world have been accustomed to receive their raw material weekly throughont the: year, there ts not a month's visible supply of this year's crop afloat and in Liverpool.

There are also other demands to be met. The "get rich quick" purchaser of suburban property, builders of "Savoy Chambers" and government officials who have taken up land in Egypt borrowed money in Europe, and the local creditors are now pressing for payment. Even the Swiss have invested largely in land which was to have been perennially fertilized by the Assouan reservoir, but is not more productive now than the Rhone glacier. The "men higher up" are to be found at the very summit of social and financial eminence.

Egypt is therefore a "creditor nation" entirely apart from the cotton crop, which, it is expected, will equal in weight and value half the copper output of the world and about double the value of the exports of the Standard Oil. There is no corner in cotton to be broken by its own weight, through interest, storage, or carrying over charges. The staple is fairly firm at from 20 to 29 cents a pound, but it sold at 40 cents in 1863, and its present price is altogether normal.

The forty thousand holders of Egyptian cotton will be perfectly willing to sell, but they want a commodity in exchange, and that commodity is gold coin. Now, if American bankers send $5,000,000 to Egypt to keep the crop moving it would be good business. It must be remembered that we have an advant age (as well as a danger) in our gold certificates. The Continental banks of issue when they pay gold are paying at least two for one, but our gold secured currency is a warehouse re ceipt for so much minted metal.

div.head: THE EMPRESS EUGENIE.
div.p: The personality of the Empress Engénie has long been familiar and sympathetic to English people, both because of her romantic and eventually tragic history, and also because ot her firm friendship with Queen Victoria. But in spite of the eagerness and interest which is still aroused by anything that concerns her recent meeting with the Austrian Emperor and her interest in the young Queen of Spain are but two illustrations—Mr. Philip W. Sergeant has set himself no easy task in attempting to tell the story of her life from such a very short perspective. It is greatly to his credit, therefore, that, while omitting no essential personal details, he has maintained an atmosphere of history throughout his story, and has left it when it became too private and personal for contemporary survey.

It is a story which might well tempt every lover of romance. Indeed, superficially it is the veritable fairy-tale, except that it lacks the "happy ever after." The most interesting part of Mr. Sergeant's book is perhaps his account of the Empress's girlhood. The time is far enough away for him to be hampered neither by the inconveniences of truth nor by the lack of perspective, and he has given us a picture which in every way foreshadows the character of the Empress of the French. The friendship of the Countess of Montijo with Mérimée was productive of many interesting notes and memories concerning the girl Eugénie and her early life, though on the whole the evidence is scanty enough. Washington Irving speaks of "having dandled her on his knee" when on a visit to Granada, but it is Mérimée alone who has recorded the essentials of what we know of her. The Countess of Montijo, a clever, talented, woman, was extremely ambitious as to her daughter's future, and was well satisfied when she married the elder of the two, Francisca, to the Duke of Berwick and Alba. This helped to give the Montijosa good position in Madrid, and it is surprising that Eugénie, with her captivating beauty, high spirits, and charm, should not have followed sooner in her sister's steps. It is suggested by the author that her somewhat "tomboy" disposition, which delighted in the unconventional, and which sometimes led her into wild pranks, may have had something to do with it. Yet it would have been remarkable had offers been lacking. There were many stories. of her being reserved for a higher destiny. At all events, she was 27 years of age before Napoleon III, invited her to share his throne.

Now that the Empress has so long obtained full recognition, and that a clear judgement of Napoleon III is gradually becoming possible, it is easy to forget the enormous obstacles which had to be overcome before he married as his heart rather than his head directed. The author does not attempt to gloss over the fact that he had already made overtures to several Royal princesses, which received but scant attention. Never theless, in spite of the insecurity of his throne, which would have heen consolidated by a Royal marriage, in spite of the serious apposition of his family and the sneers of his opponents, he remained firm in his de termination to marry a subject of Queen Isabella of Spain.
In his life of the Empress Mr. Sergeant gives a well-balanced estimate of the Emperor, at the same time quoting the views of many well-known people.
"Louis Napoleon Bonaparte," says one of them, "is endowed with incontestable power of resistance, a 'vis inertiae' ; but what he lacks in the very highest degree is the power of initiative.
Mr. Sergeant notes Moltke's remark that the French Emporor "suffers from a want of men of ability to support him," and adds further:-

If he is to be judged, it must be by the whole of his career, not merely as the Man of Sedan. And if he is thus judged by his whole work there will be found much to be said for this dreamer who. . . took neither France nor Europe into his confidence, but unaided at the start except by the equivocal sound of a great name, bent both to the acceptance of what he himself called the dictates of his reason and of his heart.

Two chapters on the Court and the notable names of the time contain nothing particularly new, but give a fair and interesting account of the human influences of the Second Empire. The friendship with England was eagerly wel comed by the Imperial pair as an official recognition of their status in Europe, and the Historic ball at Versailles brings back Victorian memories of beautiful women with curling hair and drooping shoulders, and even the ccrinoline suggests a certain romance taken in connexion with them and the beautiful Empress who introduced it.

The differences between the Emperor and Empress on the Italian question are fully discussed by the author, with particular reference to the Empress, who began to be recognized as a power after the birth of the Prince Imperial. The tragic story of the Franco-German war, the escape of the Empress, and her exchange of the Tuileries for Chislehurst, is well known, and is also described at length.
It is a fascinating story, and Mr. Sergeant has told it well. The illustrations which accompany it are good and add very greatly to the interest of an interesting book.
* "The Last Empress of the French." By Philip W. Sergeant, London Werner Laurie, 12. 6d. net.

div.head: ARITHMETIC 1700 B.C.
div.p: Probably the oldest copy book for home lessons in arithmetic was unearthed in Egypt. The papyrus, which was found in excellent con- dition, dates from the period about 1700B.C. —that is, abont 100 years before the time of Moses, or almost 8,600 years ago. It proves that the Egyptian had a thorough knowledge of elementary mathematics almost to the extent of our own. The papyrus has a long heading, "Direction how to attain the knowledge of all dark things, etc. Numerous examples show that their principal operations with entire units and fractions were made by means of addition and multiplication. Subtractions and divisions were not known in their present form, but correct results were obtained nevertheless.

Equations are also found in Papyrus. Among the examples given is this one: Ten measures of barley are to be divided among ten persons in such a manner that each subsequent persons receives one-eighth of a measure less than the one before him. Another example given is: There are seven men; each one has seven cats, each cat has eaten seven mice, each mouse has eaten seven grains of barley. Each grain of barley would, if cultivated, have yielded seven measures of barley. How much barley has been lost in that way? The papyrus also contains calculations of area, the calculation of the area of a circle and its transformation into a square and finally calculations of the cubic measurements of pyramids.

div.head:
THE LIVER IS A GOOD FRIEND
BUT A BAD ENEMY.
div.p: The liver is a large and powerful organ, composed of a great multitude of blood-vessels, nerves, absorbents, and bile channels, held together by a reddy-brown substance. The liver's great work is to supply the bile, which helps to prepare our food for converting into rich, life-giving blood.

But when the liver becomes sluggish, there is not enough bile made to digest the food, so the blood becomes starved—thin, pale, and without nourishment, and the food ferments, giving off bad gases which cause flatulency, headache, and foul breath. The bowels become clogged, and constipation begins.

One of the first signs of sluggish liver is a feeling of despondency and weariness (due to the impure blood stupifying the brain and failing to nourish the body. The complexion will be yellow, and the eyes heavy ; there will be wind in the stomach, variable appetite, palpitation of the heart, and bad taste in the month.

Liver trouble should always have prompt treatment, and, in its early stages, careful dieting, in conjuction with a thorough course of Doan's Dinner Pills, will effect a cure. But if neglected, enlargement of the liver may result, and the action of the organ may be ruined ; there will be dyspepsia, anaemia, and perhaps skin disease. The muscles that drive out the poisonous waste will be numbed, and there will be constipation. Doan's Dinner Pills are the great liver corrective ; their action is mild but reliable ; they give a healthy stimulus to the liver, so that sufficient bile is produced to digest the food and ease the passage of waste.

Doan's Dinner Pills are the best medicine for biliousness, indigestion, constipation, for headache, retching, dizziness, distress after eating, poor appetite, yellow eyes, heartburn, wind and for every liver, stomach and bowel trouble. To be had of all chemists and druggists, at 6 P.T, per box.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS IMPORTANT

SERVICE DE SECOURS MEDICAUX D'URGENCE
DE NUIT
La Municipalité d'Alexandrie informe le public qu'elle vient de créer un service de secours médiesux d'urgence de nuit, service qui fonctionnera a partir du soir du 21 Aofit 1907.

Deux stations desecours d'urgence ont été établies ; l'une a l'Attarine, rue Attarine N° 85, telephone N° 2006, l'autre 4 Goumrok, rue Halwaghi, N° 18, téléphone N° 2026. Ces deux stations sont marquées par un écriteau et une lanterne portant le croissant rouge.

Le service a été confié a six médecins. Ce sont M.M. les Docteurs Akestoridés, Civiletti et Sgouros pour la station de l'Attarine, et M M. les Docteurs Dos Galli, Kohn et Lévi pour la station de Goumrok.
Dans chaque station il y aura toutes les nuits, de 10h. p.m. a 6h. du matin, deux médecins, qui seront préts a offrir leurs soins soit dans la station méme, soit a domicile.

Les soins médicaux offerts dans la station seront gratuits. Ils seront aussi donnés gratuitement a domicile, chez les personnes payant moins de 30 L.E. de loyer annuel. De 30 a 100 L.E. de loyer la visite est fixée a 40 P.T.; au dela de 100 L.E. la visite est fixée a 80 P.T. Ces honoraires ne seront pas payés an Docteur. La Municipalité les recouvrera par l'entremise de son service de perception.
Le transport d'un blessé ou d'un malade a un hopital peut étre effectué gratuitement et a n'importe quel moment de la nuit ou de la journée par un service spécial d'ambulance.
Téléphone N° 417.

Le Vice-Président.
Dr. Schiess.
